title: How to Plant a Child Friendly Garden

steps.headline: Involve your kids in planting fruits and vegetables.
steps.description: Edible plants are a great way to get your kids interested in the garden. Ask them what they'd like to plant in this area, and encourage them to help you plant the seeds or seedlings and care for the plants as they grow. Involving your kids in these decisions will get them invested in the plants. Then, when the fresh foods appear on the table, they know they had a hand in growing them, and they'll be more likely to eat them!

steps.headline: Add herbs and other edible plants.
steps.description: Herbs are fun for kids because they can smell and taste the plants (after you give them permission!). Plus, it helps them learn about herbs used in cooking when you bring them into the kitchen and add them to your dishes and beverages. Try plants like spearmint, lavender, rosemary, basil, sage, parsley, cilantro, chives, and oregano. As an added bonus, herbs tend to be fairly hardy plants. Keep in mind that some herbs will take over whatever area you plant them in. Spearmint and lavender, for instance, tend to be aggressive.

steps.headline: Opt for wildlife-friendly plants.
steps.description: Try planting a garden for bees and pollinators so your kids can study them; single-bloom old-fashioned flowers in purples, yellows, whites, and blues are typically best. You could also plant things to encourage other wildlife to visit, such as squirrels and chipmunks, and your kids will love watching these furry creatures. Chipmunks and squirrels like fruit- and nut-bearing plants, flowers with large seeds (like sunflowers), and tall grasses, just to name a few.

steps.headline: Add ornamental grasses for sturdiness and texture.
steps.description: Grasses such as hair grass, kitten grass, Stipa gigantea, and Anemanthele lessoniana are easy to grow, easy to maintain, and put up with a lot of abuse. They can add height and texture to your garden and will hold up even if your kids accidentally tumble into them. Many also grow through the winter. Look up hardy grasses that thrive in your area.

steps.headline: Include blooming perennials for easy beauty.
steps.description: With kids running around, you may not have as much time to give to your garden as you'd like. By planting perennials in some areas of the garden, you can get gorgeous landscaping that will come back year after year and usually hold up to a bit of rough play. For example, try perennial varieties of tulips, irises, lilies, black-eyed Susans, coneflowers, and lavender. You can also plant flowering perennial bushes or small trees, such as roses, rose of Sharon, crape myrtle, hibiscus, or redbuds.

steps.headline: Designate an area for roughhousing.
steps.description: If your whole yard is a garden, it makes it difficult for kids to be kids. By setting aside an open space to play, you're encouraging them to stay out of more delicate areas! If you have large parks nearby, this area doesn't need to be huge.

steps.headline: Design your garden with kid-friendly hideaways.
steps.description: Most kids love to have little places where they can make secret clubs or just hide out and read. You can add these to your garden to make it more interesting for you and your kids. For example, create curving paths that veer around corners or circles of tall flowers or bushes. You could also leave an opening under a canopy tree, such as a weeping willow.

steps.headline: Give your kids an area where they can decide what to plant.
steps.description: Set aside a patch of dirt for each of your kids. Then, they can plant what they want in it, giving them autonomy and responsibility. It can be a small patch of dirt or even a few pots if you have limited space. Even if they just end up digging around in the dirt and not growing much, having a designated space helps kids develop an interest in gardening. After all, most kids love to mimic what they see their parents doing! Make sure to get child-sized tools for your kids so they can work in their garden.

steps.headline: Make themed areas to encourage your children's interest.
steps.description: Pick themes your kids will enjoy that will draw their attention. For example, you could plant a "pizza" garden with things like tomatoes, onions, basil, rosemary, oregano, bell peppers, and garlic. Alternatively, try a rainbow flower garden, where you plant different colors of flowers in rows, creating a rainbow. You could also create a smoothie or popsicle area with plants like blueberries, strawberries, spinach, carrots, or whatever else you like in your smoothies!

steps.headline: Avoid plants that are majorly toxic.
steps.description: While kids shouldn't be eating random plants, you do want your garden to be as safe as possible. For instance, it's best to avoid plants with berries that look edible but are actually toxic, such as nightshade, ivy, laburnum, and yew. Before planting, check the name of the plant against lists of toxic plants to make sure they aren't highly toxic. Of course, it's nearly impossible to avoid toxic plants altogether. For example, apple seeds can be poisonous in large quantities. That's why it's important to monitor your kids and teach them garden safety! Also, keep in mind that some varieties of plants are more toxic than others. For instance, some lilies are only minorly toxic, including true lilies. However, checkered, climbing, and glory lilies are all very toxic if ingested.

steps.headline: Teach your kids not to eat any part of the plant without asking you first.
steps.description: Kids are curious and will put anything in their mouths to test it! By encouraging them to always ask first, you can help them avoid eating something poisonous by accident.

steps.headline: Avoid or remove garden ponds.
steps.description: Young children can drown even in shallow water, so if you have kids under 10, it's best to keep water features out of your yard. If you want to have a water feature, make sure it's walled off with a sturdy fence your kids can't climb. Always supervise your kids around water features!

steps.headline: Place spiky or sharp plants out of the way.
steps.description: Wall these plants off with other plants to make it more difficult for your kids to stumble into them. That way, they won't get scratched or stung by these plants. Roses, cacti, some succulents, raspberries, and blackberries all have sharp parts.

steps.headline: Flush the affected area if your child comes in contact with a toxic plant.
steps.description: If they ate it, remove what's left of the plant from their mouth and rinse their mouth out with water. Then, call poison control to see if you need to do anything else. If you're not sure whether the plant is poisonous, it's always best to call. Similarly, if a plant is irritating your child's eyes or skin, remove the plant immediately. Wash the skin with soap and water or flush the child's eyes with clear running water for 10 to 15 minutes. If your child is having trouble breathing, call an ambulance. If you need to go to the emergency room, carry a piece of the plant with you in a plastic bag.

text: Deciding What to Plant Involve your kids in planting fruits and vegetables. Edible plants are a great way to get your kids interested in the garden. Ask them what they'd like to plant in this area, and encourage them to help you plant the seeds or seedlings and care for the plants as they grow. Involving your kids in these decisions will get them invested in the plants. Then, when the fresh foods appear on the table, they know they had a hand in growing them, and they'll be more likely to eat them! Add herbs and other edible plants. Herbs are fun for kids because they can smell and taste the plants (after you give them permission!). Plus, it helps them learn about herbs used in cooking when you bring them into the kitchen and add them to your dishes and beverages. Try plants like spearmint, lavender, rosemary, basil, sage, parsley, cilantro, chives, and oregano. As an added bonus, herbs tend to be fairly hardy plants. Keep in mind that some herbs will take over whatever area you plant them in. Spearmint and lavender, for instance, tend to be aggressive. Opt for wildlife-friendly plants. Try planting a garden for bees and pollinators so your kids can study them; single-bloom old-fashioned flowers in purples, yellows, whites, and blues are typically best. You could also plant things to encourage other wildlife to visit, such as squirrels and chipmunks, and your kids will love watching these furry creatures. Chipmunks and squirrels like fruit- and nut-bearing plants, flowers with large seeds (like sunflowers), and tall grasses, just to name a few. Add ornamental grasses for sturdiness and texture. Grasses such as hair grass, kitten grass, Stipa gigantea, and Anemanthele lessoniana are easy to grow, easy to maintain, and put up with a lot of abuse. They can add height and texture to your garden and will hold up even if your kids accidentally tumble into them. Many also grow through the winter. Look up hardy grasses that thrive in your area. Include blooming perennials for easy beauty. With kids running around, you may not have as much time to give to your garden as you'd like. By planting perennials in some areas of the garden, you can get gorgeous landscaping that will come back year after year and usually hold up to a bit of rough play. For example, try perennial varieties of tulips, irises, lilies, black-eyed Susans, coneflowers, and lavender. You can also plant flowering perennial bushes or small trees, such as roses, rose of Sharon, crape myrtle, hibiscus, or redbuds. Creating Children-Friendly Spaces Designate an area for roughhousing. If your whole yard is a garden, it makes it difficult for kids to be kids. By setting aside an open space to play, you're encouraging them to stay out of more delicate areas! If you have large parks nearby, this area doesn't need to be huge. Design your garden with kid-friendly hideaways. Most kids love to have little places where they can make secret clubs or just hide out and read. You can add these to your garden to make it more interesting for you and your kids. For example, create curving paths that veer around corners or circles of tall flowers or bushes. You could also leave an opening under a canopy tree, such as a weeping willow. Give your kids an area where they can decide what to plant. Set aside a patch of dirt for each of your kids. Then, they can plant what they want in it, giving them autonomy and responsibility. It can be a small patch of dirt or even a few pots if you have limited space. Even if they just end up digging around in the dirt and not growing much, having a designated space helps kids develop an interest in gardening. After all, most kids love to mimic what they see their parents doing! Make sure to get child-sized tools for your kids so they can work in their garden. Make themed areas to encourage your children's interest. Pick themes your kids will enjoy that will draw their attention. For example, you could plant a "pizza" garden with things like tomatoes, onions, basil, rosemary, oregano, bell peppers, and garlic. Alternatively, try a rainbow flower garden, where you plant different colors of flowers in rows, creating a rainbow. You could also create a smoothie or popsicle area with plants like blueberries, strawberries, spinach, carrots, or whatever else you like in your smoothies! Keeping Your Kids Safe Avoid plants that are majorly toxic. While kids shouldn't be eating random plants, you do want your garden to be as safe as possible. For instance, it's best to avoid plants with berries that look edible but are actually toxic, such as nightshade, ivy, laburnum, and yew. Before planting, check the name of the plant against lists of toxic plants to make sure they aren't highly toxic. Of course, it's nearly impossible to avoid toxic plants altogether. For example, apple seeds can be poisonous in large quantities. That's why it's important to monitor your kids and teach them garden safety! Also, keep in mind that some varieties of plants are more toxic than others. For instance, some lilies are only minorly toxic, including true lilies. However, checkered, climbing, and glory lilies are all very toxic if ingested. Teach your kids not to eat any part of the plant without asking you first. Kids are curious and will put anything in their mouths to test it! By encouraging them to always ask first, you can help them avoid eating something poisonous by accident. Avoid or remove garden ponds. Young children can drown even in shallow water, so if you have kids under 10, it's best to keep water features out of your yard. If you want to have a water feature, make sure it's walled off with a sturdy fence your kids can't climb. Always supervise your kids around water features! Place spiky or sharp plants out of the way. Wall these plants off with other plants to make it more difficult for your kids to stumble into them. That way, they won't get scratched or stung by these plants. Roses, cacti, some succulents, raspberries, and blackberries all have sharp parts. Flush the affected area if your child comes in contact with a toxic plant. If they ate it, remove what's left of the plant from their mouth and rinse their mouth out with water. Then, call poison control to see if you need to do anything else. If you're not sure whether the plant is poisonous, it's always best to call. Similarly, if a plant is irritating your child's eyes or skin, remove the plant immediately. Wash the skin with soap and water or flush the child's eyes with clear running water for 10 to 15 minutes. If your child is having trouble breathing, call an ambulance. If you need to go to the emergency room, carry a piece of the plant with you in a plastic bag.
